values: One more thing that's been keeping me busy - playing in the pit orchestra for a semi-local synagogue's winter fundraiser show, Oliver. It's been fun rehearsing, it's a short run, and I'm learning all sorts of neat things about the Jewish faith. If any of you in the nearby area are interested, tickets are available here.

OK, so it's been a little stressful - at least on my personal scale - since the holidays. Survived Christmas at Mom's, which is no small feat. At least twice on christmas eve and two or three times on christmas day I of course could not do anything right, including being accused of smacking her bratty dog when the dog in question had knocked me off balance, and in trying not to fall over I flailed and tapped her with the leash I was holding. Peeling potatoes wasn't going nearly fast enough since I don't do a whole lot of that, so she had to reach in and do some of it for me. This is life with my mother, and she doesn't understand why I never want to come over just to visit. New year's eve I chickened out, worried about more stupid drivers on ice than normal, so we stayed home. Meanwhile one of the bands I play in was gearing up for beginning of rehearsals on Jan. 8. Our director of 8 years has moved out of the area, so a new director was needed. When no-one stepped up, I said I could give it a try if no-one else came forward. A couple others did, so "auditions" were held at the first two practices, with each of us leading the band for an hour or so, then elections last night. Yeah, it went that way. So now I have to learn how to lead a bunch of adult-sized kids, and attempt to instill a bit of discipline without being a right b!tch about it. This will be interesting - in the manner of that delightful Chinese curse. On the other hand, if I survive this, I'll have one shoulder bulked up by the end of the summer. I also have finally gotten my student loan paid off. Interesting how on their graduated repayment plan it should have been paid off in may of 2008. When I was gainfully employed, I would make double payments when I could, and suddenly the monthly due dropped. After I was only semi-employed, I still made extra payments whenever I could. Ironically, in this month they decided to increase the monthly payment to almost 150% of the old payment, which was MORE THAN WAS STILL OUTSTANDING. When the final payment went through, not a peep, no notification that it was done, just the note about the amount increasing. I love beaurocracy. And of course now that I have car payments do deal with, the number of my private music students is dropping. Some of it is the after-holiday chaos, some of it is the economy, some of it is kids with no time because of sports and other activities. Le sigh. Tossing around some other ideas to make a few bucks on the side, still tuning the occasional piano. Still want to move as soon as I can get this house de-cluttered and ready to put on the market. May need to borrow the former boss' Bobcat and let Cam clear things out that way. Amazing how mush STUFF accumulates over the... 6? 7? years we've been in this house. So yeah, that's been me for the past few weeks. I know, I know, more frequent posts would keep this from being so long-winded.

Teh frozen skywaters!  Oh noes!

At least I don't have to drive far in it, with idiots on the road and a new car.
Got the permanent tags for the car, so I guess it's really official now.
Bank has deducted the first car payment right on schedule.  Only 59 more to go.  Hopefully my permanent plates will be in soon...

So I had this brilliant idea of taking some stickers intended for a car and mounting them on sheet magnets, so I could take them off for cleaning or when they wear out.  Got the magnet sheets.  Carefully mounted and cut out.  And... there's not enough metal in the back hatch of the car for the magnet to stick.

Rassafrack.
Somehow managed to top the list of Biggest Losers at Curves in october.  Only gained back a whole pound since then.  I blame the halloween candy and my lack of self-control.

After a rather long time off, I've decided to give this thing one more try before I just delete the account altogether.  I'm going to attempt to keep the whining and complaining out.  I don't wanna hear it from other people, so why should anyone wanna hear it from me?  So, general observations, news, who knows.  Perhaps the occasional bit of bad fiction.

News. 

Well, I bought a car a week and a half ago.  Finally got the Prius I'd been after for, oh, a year.  Probably could have held out a bit longer, but every time I got one thing fixed on the old car something more expensive broke.  It's taking getting used to, I'm not too comfortable with the console layout yet, and pushing a button to go into park instead of moving the shift lever up is odd.  But neat.  And not having to buy gas every week is a big plus.

Bird news:  Migrants have started to arrive, both white-throated sparrows and juncos.  Still have a stubborn pair of robins.

Latest obsessions:
king.com games.  Free if you want, or optional paid membership.  Went for the paid membership, not sure if that was a wise move.  Just one more game... 

Dungeons & Dragons Online Eberron.  
Yep, I finally gave up and tried an MMORPG, something I didn't think I would ever do.  It's free, that helps.  It's an Eberron setting, which helps immensely.  My serial ranger is back in yet another incarnation.  The pluses:  It's free.  It's a neat world.  You don't have to interact with other people if you don't want to.  Quests can be selected at different levels for more or less challenge.
The minuses:  Doesn't follow any set of D&D rules I'm familiar with, all the way.  Some things are definitely from 3.5, others definitely from 4.  Others... *shrug* something else for the online version?  Perhaps.

Two non-commercial vehicles traveling opposite directions approach a traffic light.  One intends to turn right, the other to turn left, which puts them going the same direction on the new road.  Both have a regular green light, not an arrow.  There is no non-turning traffic in the way.  Which has the right of way?

A.  The one turning left
B.  The one turning right
C.  Whichever is larger and therefore more important

And for the bonus point - see if you can figure out why this is being asked!

Dear Driver:

In the great state of Maryland (if You can dream it, We can tax it), right turns on red are legal unless posted otherwise.  However, nowhere in this state, and I believe in any state, is U-turn on red legal, no matter your age bracket nor ethnic identity.

Love and Kisses,
Me

This month marks the 5th anniversary of the MER, Mars Rover mission landings. Spirit and Opportunity, expected to work for 90 days, continue to send back data today. Found a delightful article written by an MER fan in the UK here.

Cam's already said it, but hey.  Working on laundry, have a couple of students to teach, then pack up the hubby and the dog and too many presents into the car to head for Mom's.  

Stress Level:  High

So, for what it's worth, Merry Christmas, Happy Hannukah, Joyous Yule, and Happy Non-Secular Day Off.

Mars Phoenix lander, after exceeding its expected lifespan, seems to have shut down.  Farewell big guy, and thanks for all the hard work.

http://blog.wired.com/wiredscience/2008/11/mars-phoenix-re.html

Down in the dumps today.  Trying to buck it up so I don't take it out on the students later.  I need to convince myself to think more like the dog.  

Her concerns?  Does she have a home and family?  Yep.  Comfy place to sleep?  Several.  Regular good meals?  Yep.  Treats?  Probably more than she ought to.  Her biggest problem at the moment?  It's the third straight day of overcast, so she hasn't had any sunbeams to lay in.

Need to be like the doggie.

Not enough coffee in the world.  At least not in my house.  Agreed to do early lessons this morning because I was planning on going to mom's house.  After this was agreed, mom changed her mind.  Again.  Yes, I'm grouchy.

Feeling downright nauseous about the upcoming election.  Both of the main-party candidates disgust me, and the third-party folks aren't doing much better in my eyes.  I fantasize about the day when there might actually be an honest, competent, SANE candidate out there somewhere.  Oh yes, I will vote.  Still doing research, attempting to sift through the heavy biases in the various media.  Will need to follow links provided by Slothman when I'm less grumpy.

Tempted to do a long rambling post about the things I believe and how they apply to this country, but I'm afraid I'd have to lock it to all comments.  Not in any way shape or form in the mood to listen to "I disagree so I'm right and you're wrong and how can you think that way?!!1!!" from anyone.

Maybe I should take a nap after my lessons.

Lots of laundry to do.  Should continue working on figuring out how to play the flute.  Yeah, I got a flute a while back.  Figured since I play most of the other woodwinds, I may as well add that, and there are times when it could be helpful to one of the bands I play with.  It's taking some getting used to.  Probably ought to spend some quality time with the keyboard too, I've been slacking off on the practicing there.

Concert sunday.  Need to figure out what kind of costume to wear.  Grumpy enough that I wish I could get out of it.

Seen on a t-shirt in a catalog that I order music teaching supplies from:

"Consort not with a female musician, lest thou be taken in by her snares" - Ben Sira, c. 190 B.C.

Want!

Since Mom's store closed a while ago, she and I have a LOT of leftover supplies.  Prominent are:
Knitting needles - straight, mostly 10-inch length, bamboo or polymer, assorted sizes

Cross-stitch/needlework fibers:  DMC, Anchor, and probably some overdyed somewhere.  Standard skeins and super-size cones.

Fancy yarn - intended for scarves, but could be used for highlights as well.

Perle Cotton - size 8 and 12 on balls

Cross-stitch/needlework patterns and kits - I have 4 big shopping bags full

Paternyan tapestry wool

Aida, linen, and related fabrics (cross-stitch/needlework)

There is probably more too.  If anyone is interested contact me, most of you have my email address or at least Cameron's.  I will ask a small price, but mostly they just need to GO AWAY.

OK, I remember enough geo-geekery that I've become fascinated with the Mars exploration robots and satellites. I think it's so cool that the rovers on Mars now (Spirit and Opportunity) have survived two years when they were expected to last 90 days. Especially after the failed missions several years ago. I love seeing what the scientists here are thinking up to explore next, while the little guys are still functional. OK, I saw a life-size model of one in a museum, they're not that little, but still. The latest with Opportunity - a 7-km drive to a much larger crater than the one it's been exploring for the past 2 years. No, I don't understand the science of the robotics. I leave that to and the other "real" scientists out there.

So every once in a while I have ideas for alternative fuels.  Way out there.  Some I don't dare post here, cause I'd get thrown off lj so fast I'd bounce.  But this one...

Elissa, make sure you don't have anything in your mouth.

Fuel cars with extraneous apostrophes!

So despite all the hubbub and stuff, the Large Hadron Collider has been fired up, albeit not yet at full power.  And amazingly, the universe hasn't imploded.  Now I freely admit that I don't remember much of Physics beyond basic high school level, so I dismissed the people who wanted it to never work as extremists. 

So yesterday's Washington Post had an article about it.  In the Style section with the fashion and performing arts and comics, which goes to show how much the Post knows about science.  According to the article, the people against it are worried about it making black holes.

Seriously?  Well, yeah, according to the article.  Which I take with many grains of salt given the Post's biases.  Same article says that the scientists on the project are not worried, as any black holes they make would be microscopic and only last a fraction of a second, like the ones that occur naturally in space caused by cosmic rays.

Now putting aside any opinions about whether it might be a good thing to open up a black hole under or near France, I have to ask if it's realistic?  Could this Big Gizmo actually cause a Rift In Time And Space!!! large enough that anyone other than the instruments watching would even notice?  I simply can't imagine it's -that- powerful, but as I said earlier, I don't remember much about Physics beyond basic global forces.

I know there's at least two Physicists and an Engineer (Real Scientists!) who may read this, so educate a poor musician!  Just try not to break my poor feeble brain.

Well, Teacher has taken back the book that the song was in I was maybe going to have to play.  Which means it's not my problem.  Now, I played phone tag with her for three days trying to at least get a yes or no, and never got to talk to her directly.  You would think it would at least be considered common courtesy to say something along the lines of "thanks for scrambling, but we've got it covered."  

And people wonder why I grumble about irresponsible teenagers.

Not.  My.  Problem.

Gig vs. staying the heck out of it

One of the young (high school graduate) teachers at the store comes up to me yesterday to ask a favor.  Seems her friend had asked her to play a little piano at her wedding.  Next weekend.  Teacher has evidently made other plans after forgetting that she agreed to do this.  Teacher has asked me if I can do it.

It's an excerpt from a piece that isn't too hard, with a little practice I should be able to do it fine, assuming I can get over the performance jitters - you know, the whole reason that my degree doesn't say Music Performance on it.  After some grilling of Teacher, it turns out that this is to be used as the processional.

Um. 

Well, at least no-one would be paying attention to me.

Now, there are a few questions I've had Teacher ask the Bride, I have not definitely agreed to this yet.  Things like where and when - how far away is it?  And whether or not I'd at least get gas money.  If I do this to help out Miss Teacher, she at least ought to compensate me a little for covering her butt.  Something else I will need to ask though - is the Bride OK with this?  It seems to me that Bride asked Teacher to do this because it would mean a lot to the Bride to have her friend playing her down the aisle, and since friend is effectively dissing her for something else... why not just have whoever is playing the rest of the music do it?  A "professional" pianist  - one who's doing this anyway - would find the piece quite easy.

And I'm not getting into the whole moral thing of abandoning your friend on what's supposed to be one of the biggest days of her life.  Not gettin' involved.  Just trying to decide if I -should- do this at all.

Ze test, I have smacked it around and made it my bitch.  50 wpm with 10 errors.

Now I guess I get to focus on learning touch-typing, in a less panicked state.

Next step, keep applying for positions.  Of course, the listings are supposed to update on Fridays, and haven't yet today.

So I have finally admitted, quite reluctantly, that I have to get at least a part-time job.  It was suggested that I try to weasel my way into a school system, perhaps in a secretarial position, as the hours would allow me to continue the private lessons in the evening.  

In this county, I'm sure many others as well, one needs to pass a typing test as one of the requirements for a secretarial position.  Make sense, really.  I can type pretty well as long as I can look at the keys, but my accuracy usually stinks.  So I found an online typing tutor and have been working with that.

What I have learned so far:
- I can touch-type a little, but not anywhere near fast enough for the test.  That's fine, in the test I can look at my hands.

- I stink at the top row (numbers, special characters, etc.)

- I use all the fingers except the pinky, and that only sometimes.

- I seem to be better at typing Shakespeare and Dickens than modern English, even with the non-standard punctuation they use

I will be fine for the test (scheduled Friday), but plan to continue practicing even after the test to increase speed and accuracy.  I will probably work slowly on better touch-typing, cause why not? I would think I would be able to go faster if I'm not constantly switching the eyes from the keyboard to whatever I'm reading from the to screen and such.  

As a side note, the idea of re-entering the work force is completely and utterly terrifying.

Bust - down 1 inch
Waist - no change
Abdomen - no change
Hips - down 0.5 inches
Thighs - up half inch each (muscle I hope)
Arms - down half inch each
Weight - down 4.5 lbs!
Body fat - down 0.8%
BMI - down 0.77

I've crossed the 100 workout mark, and I've now crossed the 10 pound mark.

I'll take 5 pounds of chocolate, stat!

Since 4/29:

Bust - down 1/4 "
Waist - no change
Abdomen - down 1 "
Hips (aka Rear) - no change
Thighs - down 1.5" total split between 2 legs
Arms - down 1/2" total split
Weight - down 2.5 lbs
Body fat % - down 0.3 %
BMI - down 0.43

Now back to cleaning like a madwoman.

From someone's handmade ad flyer in Curves: Summer camp classes! Taught by a MCPS (County schools) certified teacher! Learning! Activities! Feild trips! (spelled that way) Ah, yeah, somebody needs to do their homework. First off, the county doesn't certify teachers, the state does. If you're certified by the state, you can teach in any public school in any county. Second, if you were really a certified teacher, would you really make this flyer without checking your spelling?

Yeah, I'm not making nearly as much progress as I want.  Since Jan. 30:

Bust - no change
Waist -  -.5 inches
Abdomen:  -1 inch
Hips:  -1 inch
Thighs:  - 4 inches
Arms:  -1 inch
Weight: - 2 lbs
Body fat %:  -0.8%
They also measure BMI, but I have no reason to follow that really... I don't believe the "studies" and charts that evidently think anorexic 10-year old is the proper body shape for an adult.

Need to buckle down and try to squeeze my fat self into the gown so I know whether or not I need to cry and then go shopping.

Clouds cleared up enough that we could watch some of the eclipse last night. Watched until everything was in medium shadow, decided that having feeling in my fingers was good. Got a couple of grainy digiscoped shots with my battered old telescope.
Got my driver's license renewed today.  In and out fairly quickly, really.  The really amazing thing?  The clerk who helped me SPOKE ENGLISH!  As her native language even.  What a bloody concept.

You know you've got gaming on the brain when... the packet of coffee says "Tiffin Blend,"

And your brain parses it as "Tiefling Blend."

Not terribly fond of the coffee.  Too much brimstone.

OMGWTFBBQ!!!11!1!

From the director of Montgomery Village Community Band, one of the groups I play in. 

"Dear Band Members:
 
On Wednesday night we are going to record "Let's Go" for inclusion on a nationally distributed CD.  The other bands that will be represented are Virginia Grand Military Band, Federal City Brass Band, and TUSAB , Pershing's Own.  The CD will be distributed nationally by Altissimo! and offered in the same sales venues as many of the top military bands.  It will be an honor to have MVCB on this disc, so we want to give it our very best performance."  


I can honestly say I'd never dreamed of being on a nationally distributed CD.  Not that you'll be able to hear me specifically, but still.

I'm reading a book from the library.  Sci-fi genre, not really hard science but it tries to back up its fantastic ideas with real science.  There is a character who is a genius scientist but also a real raging ... not-nice person.  He uses foul language.  He takes the lord's name in vain.  This doesn't really bother me.  It takes a lot to offend me generally, and if it does I simply stop reading it.  If someone asks my opinion I will give it, but I'm not going to go around telling everyone I see not to read this OMGWTFBBQ!!!!1!!11

But someone else who had the book at some point has crossed out every time any character uses the f-bomb, or any other "bad word."  Often writing in PC alternatives.  At least in pencil, so the printed words are still quite legible.  Once she (it's feminine handwriting) felt compelled to write (Why does an intelligent author use such an unintelligent word?"  If a character says "goddamn" or "Jesus Christ" she has to alter that to, including writing "blasphemy!"

Now here's my issue.  OK, several issues. 

1 - If this book offends you so badly... who is forcing you to read it?  Just put it down and return it to the library.  The world will not come to an end.  There is no commandment that says Thou Must Finish Every Book Thou Pickest Up, No Matter How Offensive.  Are you that worried that someone will use this book to teach your children these horrible words OH NOES!!!11!!1  Funny, the book was not in any of the children's sections.

2 - IT'S NOT YOUR BOOK!  You didn't pay for it, the County did.  This is no different from spray painting crap on walls.  It's vandalism, plain and simple.  I'm pretty sure there's stuff in the Bible somewhere about respecting the property of others, I could be wrong.  All you are accomplishing is fueling your own indignant rage as someone is forcing you to read this book (see No. 1 above) and irritating the other people trying to read the book.

3 - Someone else felt the need to write in an answer, further defacing the book.  Never mind that the answer was entertaining.  Crazy gal had crossed out "jesus christ" and replaced it with "Good grief."  Answer was "Only Charlie Brown uses that, you religious prick."  It's somewhat reminiscent of written conversations on bathroom walls, and just about as juvenile.

4 - Pointless?  The authoress is never going to see this particular copy of her book, even if she does live in this county.  If you feel this is such a problem, perhaps a rational letter to her publisher?  Oh wait, you don't do rational do you, god hasn't told you that part.

OK, I think I'm done ranting.  For a moment at least.  The question out there is do I:  (A) Take an eraser to it and do my best to restore the poor book; (B) Tell the library staff about it when I finish and return it; or (C) sigh about human morons  and do nothing?

Side note - I do quite like the book, and the series so far, when I finish this one I'll do a little mini-review.
Happy Birthday to <lj user="obsessivewoman"> (sorry I'm late!) and <lj user="elissa_carey">!  Hope you have a wonderful time!
There is something just fundamentally disturbing about 60's songs and Broadway love songs and ballads... being redone as bouncy pseudo-dance mixes to be played while exercising.

Just cause. I Am A: Neutral Good GnomeRanger (4th Level)

Ability Scores:
Strength-12
Dexterity-12
Constitution-12
Intelligence-13
Wisdom-12
Charisma-11

Alignment:
Neutral Good A neutral good character does the best that a good person can do. He is devoted to helping others. He works with kings and magistrates but does not feel beholden to them. Neutral good is the best alignment you can be because it means doing what is good without bias for or against order. However, neutral good can be a dangerous alignment because because it advances mediocrity by limiting the actions of the truly capable.

Race:
Gnomes are in wide demand as alchemists, inventors, and technicians, though most prefer to remain among their own kind in simple comfort. Gnomes adore animals, gems, and jokes, especially pranks. They love to learn by personal experience, and are always trying new ways to build things. Gnomes stand 3 to 3.5 feet tall and live about 350 to 500 years.

Class:
Rangers are skilled stalkers and hunters who make their home in the woods. Their martial skill is nearly the equal of the fighter, but they lack the latter's dedication to the craft of fighting. Instead, the ranger focuses his skills and training on a specific enemy a type of creature he bears a vengeful grudge against and hunts above all others. Rangers often accept the role of protector, aiding those who live in or travel through the woods. His skills allow him to move quietly and stick to the shadows, especially in natural settings, and he also has special knowledge of certain types of creatures. Finally, an experienced ranger has such a tie to nature that he can actually draw on natural power to cast divine spells, much as a druid does, and like a druid he is often accompanied by animal companions. A ranger's Wisdom score should be high, as this determines the maximum spell level that he can cast.

Find out What Kind of Dungeons and Dragons Character Would You Be?, courtesy of Easydamus (e-mail)

Am I surprised at Ranger? Nope. Favorite type to play anyhoo. Gnome? Gnome? I'm not -that- short.

Because there is no way in hell you're going to get me into a major department store or shopping mall on the weekend this time of year.  Problem is, with my work schedule the only chance I have is early in the morning.  Some of you have heard me say that I would like mornings much better if they were closer to noon.

Thank goodness for coffee.

So:  Out to major shopping center down the road a ways.  

Time in Target (parking to pulling out) 25 minutes.  Money spent:  $175.  Impulse buys:  0  Non-gift stuff needed for the house:  $40.

Time in Best Buy:  10 minutes.  Most of which was spent trying to remember if Cam had a CD that I was looking at.  Total spent:  $15

Time in PetSmart:  15 minutes.  Money spent:  $100.  Sort-of impulse buy: 1 - a get-off-the-counter alarm for the stupid cat

And now I have to go work 9 hours.  Whee.

I've been performing in the orchestra for the local theater company's production of Amahl and the Night Visitors.  It's a cute little one-act opera, and the boy in the lead role has got some impressive vocal talent - at 10!  One of the actors, playing one of the kings, actually deigns to talk to the orchestra backstage!  He likes us!  

But.  One of the viola players has a striking resemblance to <lj user="elissa_carey"> with sandy blond hair.  I suspect Elissa would insist that _she_ is the evil twin.

I don't really know how the show's going from an audience perspective.  Where I sit I really can't see what's going on on-stage, and of course I know when a mistake happens.  Ask <lj user="cmccurry"> for a review.

So I get this package on my doorstep.  No idea who would have sent it to me "Niagra Conservation?"  Maybe some sort of nature thingy, so I don't open it for a while.  Finally flip it over and see "Watt Watchers, Allegheny Power."  The hell?  Whay is the power company sending me packages?  So I open it.  It's these new compact flourescent bulbs that evidently the power companies are pushing now.  Propaganda letter about how they last so much longer, which I believe, and supposedly draw less power, which I don't, if every home in America switched out just one bulb there would be enough saved electricity to power umpteen tens of thousands of homes.  Uh-huh.  Then on the back it says how they're trying to reduce the draw on power plants since coal-fired plants release so much mercury into the air.  And most of the page is about the safety stuff you have to do if you break one, such as clearing out the room for 15 minutes with an open window.  Why?  Because the bulb has some allegedly minute amount of.... Mercury!  So we're going to save teh erth and think of ten children by reducing coal-fired mercury emissions but make efficient bulbs with mercury in them.  That if it breaks in a home is more hazardous to teh children then a power plant.

Now I haven't done all my research on these bulbs, so I welcome scientific opinions.  It seems to me that if they want more energy efficient and longer lasting bulbs, there's these things called LEDs, been around for decades.  I know they make light bulbs with them.

Various blowing snow flurries yesterday with biting strong wind.  Dog is not amused.  Today seems to be continuing the theme of wind so strong you can't close the car door.  And tomorrow they're calling for a little snow, only 1-2 inches but snow nonetheless.

Started some online shopping.  Found something I thought hubby would like, sent the link to my mom since she needs stuff for him.  Her reaction?  "Good grief it looks like it's x-rated!"  Which it is NOT, mind you, but the cover certainly looks it.  Can't go into more detail since hubby reads this.  :-)

For those who observe it, happy first night of Hannukah tonight!

... like retail for the holidays.  Ugh.  Have persuaded the Owners to let me open at noon on weekdays for the holiday season.  Admittedly I am keeping at 2 on the day I do bookkeeping for Owner Q so that I have a chance in hell of actually making it on time.  Brought my laptop in Friday, since I was expecting about an hour of actual work and three of nap.

I didn't sit down for three and a half hours, and that was only to wolf lunch.  2 guitars in 2 hours, and various other schtuff.  Yeah, I know the Big Stores probably sell ten an hour, but for a little shop that's pretty damn good. 

Then went to rehearsal for the holiday show next weekend.  Wasn't quite on my game, but OK.  Proceeded to not sleep well that night.  

Because of course, I was coming down with a cold.  Taught two of my four lessons saturday - the two adults didn't make it - then went home and proceeded to be a bum and bore Cam to death.  This morning not much better.  Random violent sneezes and come-and-go nausea.  Yay!  

And this week promises to be interesting.  10 hour work day monday, interspersed with racing home on breaks to feed and walk the doggie since Cam is away, then race to rehearsal to 10 or so.  Repeat tuesday with an hour less at work.  Quite possibly repeat wednesday, although Cam should be home to take care of the dog by late morning. 

Then the holiday show thursday, friday, and saturday, and a different show for one of the community bands on sunday.  

Then I think the music stuff is done until january, other than at most two rehearsals for band.  

And no, I haven't even started on the gift shopping yet.  Planning on doing some online shopping today while I'm being a bum and trying to keep food in my stomach.

On Gypsy:  Last weekend was OK.  Opening night the audience was about the same size as the cast.  Saturday was better, good responsive audience.  Sunday I wasn't there, but I'm told the audience was NOT responsive.  So we go to this weekend - last night.  First act went well, we thought.  They were filming for the $35 show DVD (too stiff for me!).  Intermission goes on.  And on.  We start getting restless.  Then Director sneaks out and talks to Conductor.  Director then goes up on stage and gets the audience's attention.  Two of the actors, including one of the female leads (Mama Rose) are "violently ill" and cannot continue.  We give them one of the fun stripper numbers from Act 2 and send them home, Director says if they bring their ticket stubs back tonight or sunday they can get in with it.   Here's hoping that all is well tonight.

Yesterday afternoon I went over to a friend/coworkers house to take apart his piano.  Need to get hands-on experience as I'm learning how to tune the darn things.  It's different.  His piano's in pretty sad shape, but I fiddled about.  Nice feeling to go from twangy out of tune western-movie sound on two unison strings to suddenly sounding like it's supposed to.  Discovered that while y ear is pretty good, it will take a lot more practice to be able to do proper temperment by ear.  But that's why I spent $700 on a strobe tuner.  I need to get a lot more time in with my hands in a piano, but with the help of the strobe tuner I think I can do this.

And this is -why- we take the train to Thanksgiving.  I get a call from Amtrak, to tell us about a schedule change.  I think Oh CRAP!  But no, they just want to let us know that the train going down will be 11 minutes late, and the one going back will be 15 minutes late into the respective stations.  

Now mind you, last year we left DC about half an hour late and got stuck in construction traffic - yes, on the train.  Had a little break in the middle of a swamp in Virginia.  I ate lunch and watched birds.  Cam slept.

Clickety, clackety.

Tech week for the Local Theater Company production of Gypsy.  Director has become a screaming psycho.  Evidently you have to be a psycho to direct.  Actors were dropping lines all night.  Mics were not all working.  Props were not where they needed to be.  Props were still being built - nothing like trying to hear a cue line over circular saws.  Hopefully tonight will be better.

If anyone actually wants to see this thing, I can get up to 5 tickets (total, not each night.)  One may be spoken for (Cam?)

Edit:  Might help if I posted the show times, eh?  October 26-28 and November 2-4; Friday and Saturday 8pm, Sunday 4 pm, in Germantown (Clarksburg High School)  I will not be at the Oct 28 show as I have a concert with one of my other bands (which is open to the public and FREE).

So the delightful owners of my store have been crunching numbers for a while since the store isn't making them thousands of dollars a month.  They have decided that the numbers are now showing that we pay the teachers for an average of 50 lessons per month that we don't take in money for.

I'm calling bullshit.  I watch the lesson counts and money very closely, and there are no more than 5 per month.  Something is wrong with the way the numbers are being crunched, but since I'm not privy to their magical formulas I don't know where the problem is. 

Their idea to solve it?  Charge the students per month as we do, but do not offer credits and such for re-schedules or vacations.  If a student misses a lesson, it's up to them and the teacher to find a make-up day.   Which all the other stores in the area do. 

Fine.  What the f ever.  So we'll lose a few students, and even though everyone else does it, if they storm off to go somewhere else, they WON'T COME BACK because they're pissed.

Next, they want to pay the teachers monthly instead of weekly.  I think they want to do a flat monthly rate, which makes no sense whatsoever as the student count changes week to week.  So if a teacher books 10 new students in the course of a month, they won't see the money for 3-7 weeks?  Like hell.  How are you going to run a school with no teachers?  There are several teachers who rely on the weekly income to get them through each week, and who cannot budget out a month.  So they'll save all this money... and promptly lose half the students when several major teachers leave.  Myself and another teacher have fully half the current students.

So I won't be sleeping tonight, that's for sure.

My goodness. The link below is to a video from the show "Britain's Got Talent," which appears to be their equivalent of American Idol. I don't know which came first, someone with more motivation can look it up. Anyway, watch this video. Watch part 2 which is linked on the page. Giddy, I think even you will appreciate this guy. I only wish we could get talent like this on the show here in the States. Britain's Got Talent

So I went to Strasburg VA to play with a Stammtisch Band (traditional german beerhall band.  I'd provide a link, but the only good references I can find are all in German).  The director of the Montgomery Village band that I play oboe in has resources and connections and needed players for the gig.

The gig, in general was fun.  More importantly, it was PAID!  (Which is why I was willing to go 2 hours each way to get there.)  I though the town Oktoberfest was going to be a huge deal, and it wasn't.  Dragged Cam along and he was bored stiff within five minutes.  My playing was pretty much abysmal.  Oh, I could scare up all sorts of excuses from extreme heat (it -was- bloody hot) to low blood sugar to a bad case of the jitters, but it boils down to what I really knew all along.  I'm just not good enough on clarinet.  I guess I needed this to take my poor timid ego down a notch.

I'm supposed to do another show on the 18th, but I'm not sure if I'll really be needed - I don't know if Dr. Bowie will want me back even playing support.

Muse has been flogging me again. Have started the Religion section of the player's guide, which will update periodically over the weekend until the writer's block kicks in again. The Player's Guide in progress
